pathway: Pharmacy First – Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) – adolescents and adults
notes: CSOM describes persistent otorrhoea through a tympanic membrane perforation (≥6 weeks) and carries risk of cholesteatoma.
Document baseline hearing, duration of discharge, and any previous ear surgery.
Topical quinolone drops are preferred when available; avoid aminoglycosides if the middle ear is open to reduce ototoxic risk.
Always safety-net for intracranial complications — worsening headache, vertigo, facial palsy or systemic illness requires urgent assessment.

decisionTree.title: Confirm CSOM features
decisionTree.question: Is there persistent or recurrent otorrhoea through a perforated tympanic membrane for ≥6 weeks?
details: Chronic mucoid or purulent discharge, often foul smelling
History of previous acute otitis media, trauma or grommet insertion
Conductive hearing loss, tympanic membrane perforation or retraction pocket
Exclude otitis externa (tender tragus/pinna) or acute mastoiditis

yes.title: Red-flag complications
yes.question: Does the patient have suspected complications?

emergency: Severe headache, photophobia, vomiting or neurological deficit (intracranial spread)
Facial nerve weakness, vertigo or nystagmus
Post-auricular swelling, mastoid tenderness, systemically very unwell
cholesteatoma: Offensive discharge with granulation tissue or polyp in canal
History of attic retraction pocket or keratin debris
Progressive conductive hearing loss despite dry ear

yes.title: Immediate ENT referral
actions: Escalate care via GP, ENT on-call or A&E depending on severity; consider intravenous antibiotics.
Document neurological findings and do not instil drops if intracranial spread suspected.

no.title: Eligibility for community management
no.question: Screen for Pharmacy First exclusions
details: Under 12 years of age or unable to comply with ear-drop technique
Recent ear surgery (<6 weeks) other than grommet removal
Aminoglycoside allergy or previous ototoxic reaction
Systemic symptoms (fever, severe pain) despite oral therapy

yes.title: Refer to GP or ENT clinic
actions: Arrange routine ENT/audiology appointment and provide interim ear-care advice.
Advise patient to keep ear dry and avoid swimming until reviewed.

no.title: Previous cultures or antibiotic exposure
no.question: Has the patient used topical or oral antibiotics in the last month?

yes.title: Treatment failure pathway
actions: Arrange culture-guided therapy via GP/ENT; advise against repeating same empirical agent.
Provide analgesia and reinforce dry ear precautions.

no.title: Select topical therapy
no.question: Is a quinolone drop available under local PGD?

next.title: Ciprofloxacin 0.3% ear drops

dose.regimen: 5 drops into affected ear(s) twice daily after thorough aural toilet

formulations: Single-use vials or 5 mL dropper bottle
plus: Position patient with ear upward for 5 minutes after dosing; gently pump tragus.
If discharge is thick, wick or microsuction prior to first dose where available.
Arrange review in 7 days; extend to 14 days only if improving but not yet dry.
next.followUp: Return if no improvement in 3–5 days or if vertigo/tinnitus worsens

next.title: Alternative management
actions: Arrange GP/ENT review for prescription of topical quinolone or systemic therapy.
Consider acetic acid 2% for mild discharge while awaiting review, ensuring no pain or cellulitis.
Provide written safety-net advice for meningitis signs, sudden hearing loss or worsening pain.

no.title: Diagnosis uncertain
actions: If discharge duration <6 weeks or TM intact, follow acute otitis media or otitis externa pathways.
Consider referral for otomicroscopy to confirm perforation or cholesteatoma.
